dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, big tech news this week, Host_B. We've got Zuckerberg and Dorsey, like, squaring off, but also, surprisingly, kind of aligning on a huge issue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, big tech news this week, Host_B. We've got Zuckerberg and Dorsey, like, squaring off, but also, surprisingly, kind of aligning on a huge issue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now the two billionaire tech founders are at odds over how to handle free speech and political advertising, defending opposite views of a heavily debated internet issue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild, isn't it? For so long, Dorsey was championing, you know, real identity, and Mark was, like, all about anonymity, and now... this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild, isn't it? For so long, Dorsey was championing, you know, real identity, and Mark was, like, all about anonymity, and now... this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, Zuckerberg built a social network employing strict rules about using your real identity, while Dorsey and Twitter championed anonymity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And specifically, it's about political advertising and free speech. Facebook just announced they're embracing political ads, saying that political messages should be *bought*, not earned.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And specifically, it's about political advertising and free speech. Facebook just announced they're embracing political ads, saying that political messages should be bought, not earned.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that's a pretty big shift, especially since, um, Twitter, under Dorsey, previously restricted politicians from making false claims in ads.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's a pretty big shift, especially since, um, Twitter, under Dorsey, previously restricted politicians from making false claims in ads.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorseys comments took aim at how Zuckerberg has defended Facebooks political ads policy, which allows politicians and political candidates to make false claims in advertisements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But then Dorsey, ironically, had been campaigning for this exact thing, free speech and political advertising, just before Zuck made his big announcement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then Dorsey, ironically, had been campaigning for this exact thing, free speech and political advertising, just before Zuck made his big announcement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The announcement from Dorseys Twitter account came on the cusp of Facebooks scheduled third-quarter earnings call and after a month of relentless campaigning from Zuckerberg on the issue of political advertising and free speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's what made Zuck's tweet so interesting, "free expression, not paying for reach." It felt a little, uh, pointed, don't you think?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's what made Zuck's tweet so interesting, free expression, not paying for reach. It felt a little, uh, pointed, don't you think?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt about free expression, Dorsey said in a series of tweets. This is about paying for reach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. He was clearly taking a shot at how Dorsey had defended Twitter's past policy, like, "most people want to live in a world where you can only post things tech companies judge to be 100% false."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. He was clearly taking a shot at how Dorsey had defended Twitter's past policy, like, most people want to live in a world where you can only post things tech companies judge to be one hundred percent false.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I dont think most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% true, Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then Zuck added that bit, like, "we're working hard to stop gaming our systems... *buuut* if someone doesn't pay us, well, they can't say whatever they want!" And the wink emoji.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then Zuck added that bit, like, we're working hard to stop gaming our systems... but if someone doesn't pay us, well, they can't say whatever they want! And the wink emoji.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorsey added a less veiled shot to the thread as well, noting it wouldnt be credible to say: Were working hard to stop people from gaming our systems to spread misleading info, buuut if someone pays us to target and force people to see their political ad well ... they can say whatever they want! Then, he added a wink.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The wink! So much shade. But it wasn't just Zuck throwing punches. Dorsey also, um, called Zuckerberg's storytelling "inauthentic" at one point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The wink! So much shade. But it wasn't just Zuck throwing punches. Dorsey also, um, called Zuckerberg's storytelling inauthentic at one point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There's some amount of revisionist history in all his storytelling, Dorsey said of Zuckerberg. It takes away from the authenticity and the genuineness of what we're trying to do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He did! But then, weirdly, when asked about joining Facebook's Libra project, he just said, "Hell, yes." Like, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He did! But then, weirdly, when asked about joining Facebook's Libra project, he just said, Hell, yes. Like, what?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When asked if he would join Facebooks Libra project, Dorsey had a simple answer: Hell, no.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And then Zuckerberg, on the flip side, actually praised Twitter for its efforts to fix network health. Like, "they face the same issues we do."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And then Zuckerberg, on the flip side, actually praised Twitter for its efforts to fix network health. Like, they face the same issues we do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 1, when The Verge published leaked audio from a Facebook company meeting, Zuckerberg mocks Twitter and its efforts to fix the health of their network. Its why Twitter cant do as good of a job as we can, Zuckerberg said. I mean, they face, qualitatively, the same types of issues. But they cant put in the investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's like this bizarre dance. They're jousting, they're rivals, but ultimately, they're both facing this huge pressure about disinformation ahead of, uh, the 2020 election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's like this bizarre dance. They're jousting, they're rivals, but ultimately, they're both facing this huge pressure about disinformation ahead of, uh, the twenty twenty election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The afternoon jousting added to a growing public spat between the two Internet moguls, both facing pressure to eliminate massive disinformation campaigns on their networks ahead of the 2020 general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're both, like, trying to navigate this incredibly tricky landscape, even if they sometimes, um, throw a little digital dirt at each other.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're both, like, trying to navigate this incredibly tricky landscape, even if they sometimes, um, throw a little digital dirt at each other.
